questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of confusion, sweating, tremors, and loss of consciousness, particularly during fasting and after exercise. These symptoms resolve after eating. Blood tests during an episode show hypoglycemia with elevated C-peptide levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Insulinoma

  • Insulin-producing pancreatic tumor.
  • Incidence: 1-4 per million; most are benign and solitary.
  • Clinical Presentation: Neuroglycopenic symptoms (confusion, tremors, coma) typically triggered by fasting or exercise.
  • Diagnosis: Whipple's triad
    • symptoms induced by fasting;
    • hypoglycemia at the time of symptoms;
    • symptoms relieved by administration of glucose.
  • Confirmed by 72-hour fast test, showing hypoglycemia with elevated insulin and C-peptide.
  • Management:
    • Surgical enucleation is the treatment of choice.
    • Medical management includes diazoxide to suppress insulin secretion.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Factitious hypoglycemia: Typically caused by the administration of exogenous insulin, which would show low C-peptide levels.
  2. Insulinoma: A rare, insulin-producing tumor of the pancreas. Diagnosed by Whipple's triad: symptoms during fasting, hypoglycemia, and symptom relief with glucose. Elevated insulin and C-peptide during hypoglycemia confirm endogenous hyperinsulinism.
  3. Dumping syndrome: Usually occurs after gastric surgery and presents with postprandial symptoms, not fasting hypoglycemia.
  4. Postprandial syndrome: Hypoglycemia occurs after eating, not while fasting.

Key Points:

  • 90% of insulinomas are benign.
  • Part of MEN 1 in 10% of cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent peptic ulcers and diarrhea. Despite adequate medical management with proton pump inhibitors, his symptoms persist. a secretin stimulation test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome

  • Non-β islet cell tumor of the pancreas that secretes excessive gastrin, leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES).
  • Clinical Presentation: Peptic ulcers (often multiple), diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated fasting serum gastrin and positive secretin stimulation test.
  • Management: Surgical resection of the gastrinoma if no metastasis is present. Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for symptom control.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Correct. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES): Caused by gastrinoma, leading to excessive gastrin secretion and severe peptic ulcer disease, often refractory to medical treatment. Confirmed by elevated fasting serum gastrin and secretin stimulation test.
  2. Incorrect: Duodenal ulcer: Can cause recurrent ulcers but is less likely to present with such high serum gastrin levels.
  3. Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis: Causes epigastric pain and steatorrhea but doesn't lead to hypergastrinemia or recurrent ulcers.
  4. Incorrect: Factitious gastrinoma: No such entity exists.

Key Points:

Part of MEN 1 in 20-25% of cases. Tumors mostly found in the "gastrinoma triangle".

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of profuse watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and episodes of hypotension. He has lost 10 kg in the past 3 months. Physical examination reveals signs of dehydration. Blood tests show significant hypokalemia. A CT scan reveals a mass in the pancreas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
VIPoma

  • VIPoma is a rare functional tumour, accounting for ~1% of pancreatic endocrine tumors.
  • Clinical Presentation: Characterised by profuse watery diarrhoea, hypokalemia, and dehydration (Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera). Weight loss is common due to prolonged diarrhea.
  • Management: Surgical resection is the treatment of choice. Medical management includes correcting dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Octreotide may be used to control symptoms.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Incorrect: Insulinoma - Typically presents with hypoglycemia and symptoms such as weakness, tremors, and sweating, not profuse diarrhea.
  2. VIPoma - VIPoma's are characterized by profuse watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and dehydration. The patient's symptoms and weight loss are consistent with this diagnosis.
  3. Incorrect: Gastrinoma - Often presents with recurrent peptic ulcer disease and complications like perforation or hemorrhage.
  4. Incorrect: Glucagonoma - Typically presents with a migratory necrolytic rash, diabetes, and significant weight loss, which are absent in this case.

Key Points:

VIPoma presents with watery diarrhoea and hypokalemia.Surgical resection is the main treatment.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male infant from a family with a known history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2B (MEN 2B) has tested positive for a specific RET mutation associated with the syndrome. There is no evidence of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) on imaging, and his calcitonin levels are mildly elevated. What is the recommended next step in managing this infant?
questions.solution:
MEN Type 2A and 2B

  • MEN 2A: Associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.
  • MEN 2B: Associated with MTC, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas, but no parathyroid disease.

RET Mutation: A genetic mutation in the RET proto-oncogene leads to the development of MEN 2 syndromes.

Surgery in MEN 2B:

  • Timing: Prophylactic thyroidectomy should be performed as soon as possible within the first year of life to prevent the development of MTC.
  • Screening: Calcitonin levels are monitored to detect early C-cell hyperplasia, but surgery is recommended before any cancer is detectable.

Surgery in MEN 2A:

  • Prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended before 5 years of age depending on the specific RET mutation. Genetic testing and family history are crucial in determining the timing.

Explanation Of Options:

  • Annual calcitonin screening alone is not sufficient for MEN 2B patients.
  • In MEN 2B patients, prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended within the first year of life due to the high risk of early-onset MTC.
  • Waiting until 5 years old increases the risk of MTC development in MEN 2B patients, making early surgery crucial.
  • Chemotherapy is not indicated for prophylaxis in MEN 2B; surgery is the preventive measure for medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Key Points:

MEN 2B patients should undergo prophylactic thyroidectomy within the first year of life to prevent medullary thyroid carcinoma.

choices.text: Immediate surgery without further medical management

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with episodes of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. He has intermittent hypertension and has recently experienced weight loss. His biochemical tests show elevated plasma metanephrines. A CT scan reveals a well-defined adrenal mass with central necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma

  • Tumours arising from the adrenal medulla, secreting catecholamines (e.g., adrenaline, noradrenaline).
  • Symptoms: Classic triad of headache, sweating, and palpitations. Also presents with hypertension (paroxysmal or continuous).
  • Biochemical Diagnosis: Plasma or 24-hour urinary metanephrines (elevated in pheochromocytoma).
  • Imaging: CT or MRI to localise the tumour. MIBG scans if extra-adrenal or metastatic disease is suspected.
  • Preoperative Management: Alpha-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) is necessary to prevent hypertensive crises during surgery. Beta-blockade is added if needed for tachycardia.
  • Surgical Management: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is preferred for most cases unless the tumour is large (>10 cm) or shows signs of malignancy.

Explanation of Options :

  1. Incorrect. Surgery without preoperative management is dangerous due to catecholamine surges during surgery, potentially leading to hypertensive crises.
  2. Correct. Preoperative alpha-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) is essential to control blood pressure and prevent intraoperative complications. After adequate blockade, surgery is safe.
  3. Incorrect. Chemotherapy is not the first-line treatment for phaeochromocytoma.
  4. Incorrect. Radiotherapy is not typically used in the management of phaeochromocytoma.

Key Points:

  • Classic Triad: Headache, sweating, palpitations.
  • Preoperative Alpha-Blockade: Essential for preventing complications during surgery.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with malaise, abdominal pain, and palpable mass. On investigation, the child is found to have elevated urinary catecholamines. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma

  • A malignant tumour originating from the sympathetic nervous system, often affecting the adrenal medulla, sympathetic ganglia.
  • Incidence: Most common extracranial solid malignancy in children; accounts for 7% of all childhood cancers.
  • Pathology: Derived from neuroblasts. MYCN amplification indicates poor prognosis.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include malaise, pain, abdominal mass, and sometimes paraplegia. Metastases are present in 70% of cases.
  • Diagnosis: Urinary catecholamines (metanephrines), imaging (CT/MRI, MIBG), and biopsy.
  • Treatment: Surgery for low-risk patients; multi-agent chemotherapy for intermediate and high-risk cases.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Incorrect: Wilm's Tumor typically presents with an abdominal mass, but urinary catecholamines are not elevated.
  2. Incorrect: Hepatoblastoma presents with liver-related symptoms and does not cause elevated catecholamines.
  3. Neuroblastoma often presents with a palpable abdominal mass, elevated urinary catecholamines, and metastases.
  4. Incorrect: Retinoblastoma involves the eyes and doesn't present with abdominal mass or elevated catecholamines.

Key Points:

  • MYCN Amplification: Poor prognosis marker.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated urinary catecholamines in 24-hour collection.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male undergoes a CT scan for non-specific abdominal pain, and an incidental 5 cm adrenal mass is discovered. The patient has no symptoms. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Adrenal Incidentaloma

  • An asymptomatic adrenal mass discovered incidentally during imaging not performed for suspected adrenal pathology.
  • Prevalence: Incidentalomas are found in 2-10% of scans, increasing with age.
  • Evaluation:
    • > 40 mm and HU >10 are suspicious of malignancy.
    • CT/MRI: Evaluate washout characteristics and Hounsfield units.
  • Is it functional? Check for hormone secretion:
    • 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test for cortisol excess.
    • Plasma or urinary metanephrines for pheochromocytoma.
    • Aldosterone-renin ratio for hyperaldosteronism.

Management:

  • Tumors >40 mm or functionally active: Surgery.
  • Tumors <40 mm and non-functioning: Regular imaging follow-up (6 monthly)
  • Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is recommended for tumors suspicious of malignancy but <60 mm without invasion.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Biopsy is generally avoided in adrenal masses due to the risk of hypertensive crises in pheochromocytoma.
  2. Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is reserved for functioning tumors or masses >6 cm.
  3. The next step is to assess whether the adrenal mass is hormonally active, starting with plasma or urinary metanephrines to rule out pheochromocytoma.
  4. Observation alone is not appropriate until the mass is ruled out as non-functioning and benign.

Key Points:

  • Small, non-functioning tumours <40 mm require follow-up.
  • Tumours >40 mm or those showing hormonal activity require adrenalectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with central obesity, hypertension, facial plethora, and proximal muscle weakness. She also reports difficulty controlling her blood sugar levels. A physical examination reveals a "buffalo hump" and purple striae on the abdomen. Initial biochemical investigations show elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels. Further tests reveal low ACTH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cushing's Syndrome

  • A state of hypercortisolism, either ACTH-dependent (Cushing's disease or ectopic ACTH production) or ACTH-independent (adrenal adenomas or exogenous steroids).
  • Epidemiology:
    • ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas (Cushing's disease) account for 70-80% of cases.
    • Adrenal Cushing's(syndrome ) is less common (10-15%), and ectopic ACTH syndrome constitutes about 10%.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Obesity
    • Hypertension
    • Facial plethora
    • Glucose intolerance/diabetes
    • Proximal muscle weakness
    • Osteoporosis
    • Purple abdominal striae
    • Easy bruising, hirsutism, menstrual irregularities common.
  • Diagnosis:
  • Initial Biochemical Tests:
    • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (UFC): >3x upper limit of normal suggests Cushing's.
    • Late-night salivary cortisol: Loss of diurnal rhythm confirms hypercortisolism.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgery: Adrenalectomy for adrenal tumours.
    • Medical: If surgery is contraindicated, cortisol-lowering medications (e.g., ketoconazole, metyrapone).
  • Explanation of Options:
  • Incorrect. ACTH-dependent Cushing's disease (also called Cushing's disease) is characterized by elevated ACTH levels due to a pituitary adenoma. In this case, the patient has low ACTH, ruling out Cushing's disease.
  • Incorrect. Ectopic ACTH secretion is typically seen in small-cell lung cancer or neuroendocrine tumors, where ACTH levels are elevated, not decreased as in this case.
  • Correct. Adrenal Cushing's syndrome is characterized by low ACTH levels due to autonomous secretion of cortisol by an adrenal adenoma or carcinoma. The clinical features, such as central obesity, hypertension, and striae, are consistent with hypercortisolism.
  • Incorrect. Iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome is due to exogenous steroid use, which is not reported in the patient's history.

Key Points:

  • Cushing's syndrome is most commonly caused by Cushing's disease but can also result from adrenal tumours or ectopic ACTH production.
  • Adrenal Cushing's syndrome is ACTH-independent with low ACTH levels.
